ygData.msgSnippet: ... you ... don t ... accumulation ... would ... I think the problem here is that we are speaking in general terms about several distinct situations.  For

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Fri, 04 Jun 2004 00:17:33 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
> <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > Well sure I agree that is bloat, but it's only bloating because 
you
> > are adding structure faster than it can be evaluated.  
> 
> But according to the arguments I'm hearing in this thread, you 
don't
> necessarily think it is necessary to immediately evaluate all
> structure, right?  I thought I heard you arguing for the 
accumulation
> of untested structure, in the hope that at some *later* point it 
would
> prove beneficial.
> 
> So if accumulations of structure that aren't contributing to the
> fitness of the organism aren't bloat, then what is?
> 

I think the problem here is that we are speaking in general terms 
about several distinct situations.  For example, to say "NEAT is 
based on a gradualist philosophy" or "bloat is bad" and ask whether 
such statements are true or false is entirely missing the complex 
nuances of the dynamics of a system like this.  It depends on the 
situation; blanket statements don't capture the reality.

What I am saying is this:

-If fitness is consistently improving, then structure should be 
added gradually and in increments, while leaving the smaller 
structures around as well until they fall behind in fitness.  

-If fitness is stagnating, the range of spaces being explored should 
be expanded.  If fitness is stagnating, it is *not* a good idea to 
try to add structure only gradually and evaluate every little bit to 
see whether its an improvement because whatever you add may have no 
effect until you enter a sufficiently large space to express a 
better solution.

-"Not contributing to fitness" is different than "reducing 
fitness."  You are using these terms interchangeably.  If I am 
stagnating and I manage to add structure that does not reduce 
fitness, that is a good thing, not a bad thing, because I'm 
increasing my range of candidate spaces.

-Duplicating a "good" gene in DNA is really not the same as taking 
one good thing and getting two of them.  The goodness of a gene is 
completely context-dependent and a lot of the time duplicating it in 
a new context has absolutely no immediate benefit, just as adding 
new neural structure may have no immediate benefit, yet no cost on 
performance either.

-"Accumulation of untested structure" is a misnomer (you said I was 
arguing against it, but it's not what I'm talking about).  All 
structure should be tested.  If you let untested structure 
accumulate, fitness would plunge.  The point is to allow tested 
neutral structure to accumulate during periods of stagnation, but 
only in certain species.  That is not bloat, that's good policy.

> Colin suggests keeping such structure around for a certain amount 
of
> time, and then after a certain period of stagnation, killing those
> organisms off.  Is it only bloat after it has been given a large
> number of generations to try to prove itself?
> 
> > Again, it's kind of loaded to call it "superfluous."  You are 
assuming
> > what you're trying to prove in a way.  That extra structure may 
be
> > necessary, as Colin's been saying.  But I also wonder if it slows
> > anything down anyway.  In general the performance of anything
> > surviving in NEAT that has more structure is in the ballpark of 
the
> > performance of things with less structure.  In other words, you 
don't
> > end up keeping around extra structure that severely cripples
> > performance.  So where are you seeing the slowdown?  
> 
> It increases the network activation, compatibility calculation, and
> the dimensionality of the search.
> 

The point with NEAT is that we are trying to get access to good 
parts of high-dimensional space.  To say that increasing 
dimensionality is flat out bad is a generalization.  NEAT is based 
on the philosophy that starting search *directly* in high-
dimensional space is not going to work, so you have to ascend into 
it.  But certainly when lower-dimensional spaces have been 
exhaustively searched, expanding dimensionality is a good idea, not 
a bad one.

> If these aren't really issues, then why doesn't NEAT start with a
> range of complexity in the initial population?  The more complex
> individuals in the initial population will perform as well as the 
less
> complex individuals.
> 

But that's the whole point: complex individuals *won't* perform as 
well as simple ones if you just start out with a range like that!  
But if you build up to higher levels of complexity than they will 
eventually perform better than their simpler counterparts.  There is 
an event of ascension that happens when the complex networks surpass 
the others; that's why we are investing in the future by protecting 
innovation- we eventually anticipate these more complex genotypes 
becoming better.

ken
